questions.text: Which condition does not cause nasal septal perforation?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

Rhinophyma is a benign tumour of the nose due to hypertrophy of sebaceous glands of the tip of the nose. It does not involve the nasal septum.

Causes of septal perforation include:

  • Trauma: Most common causes: Nose picking, nasal surgery, septal hematoma, foreign bodies
  • Cocaine snorting, decongestant nasal sprays (Option A)
  • Chronic granulomatous diseases like tuberculosis, leprosy, and lupus cause perforation of the cartilaginous part of the septum. (Option B)
  • Syphilis causes perforation of the bony part of the septum
  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis causes perforation of both parts of the septum. (Option D)

questions.text:
False about Caldwell-Luc operation:
a. Infraorbital nerve damage may occur as complication
b. Opening of maxillary antrum through gingivobuccal incision
c. Used for the treatment of chronic maxillary sinusitis & for obtaining biopsy for antral malignancy
d. Sublabial approach leading to opening of mandibular antrum may be done under local anaesthesia with nerve block
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Caldwell-Luc Operation technique accesses the maxillary antrum, not the mandibular antrum; hence, the statement is wrong.

Caldwell-Luc Operation (Anterior Antrostomy):

  • The Caldwell-Luc operationinvolves opening the maxillary antrum through the canine fossa using a sublabial approach.
  • It's also known as anterior antrostomyas it provides access to the maxillary sinus through the anterior wall.

Indications: (Statement c)

  1. Chronic Maxillary Sinusitis:When there are irreversible changes in the sinus mucosa.
  2. Suspected Neoplasm:To biopsy suspected tumours in the antrum.
  3. Maxillary Artery Ligation:Approaching the pterygopalatine fossa for ligation of the maxillary artery.

Operational Procedure:

  • The procedure is performed under general anaesthesia.
  • A cuffed endotracheal tube is inserted into the trachea to secure the airway and facilitate mechanical ventilation during surgery.
  • A pharyngeal packis used to minimise the risk of blood or fluids entering the throat or trachea.
  • Incision:A horizontal incision is made below the gingivolabial sulcus, from the lateral incisor to the second molar. (Statement b)
  • Mucoperiosteal Flap:The mucoperiosteal flap is then raised from the canine fossa to the infraorbital nerve, ensuring nerve protection. The infraorbital nerve runs in the roof of the maxillary sinus and can be injured. (Statement a)

choices.text: Osteomas are most commonly seen in frontal sinus
Malignancy is most common in Maxillary sinus
Fungal balls are most common in Ethmoid sinus
Mucoceles are most common in Frontal sinus

questions.text: Which statement about sinonasal conditions is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • Fungal balls or aspergilloma are primarily maxillary, with ethmoid involvement being rare.
  • Osteomas, benign bony growth, are most common in the frontal sinus. (Option A)
  • Among the paranasal sinuses, the maxillary sinus is the most common site for sinonasal malignancies. (Option B)
  • Mucoceles are most common in the frontal sinus. (Option D)

choices.text: Total Maxillectomy in carcinoma of maxillary sinus
Partial Maxillectomy in osteoma of maxillary sinus
Prognostic evaluation of carcinoma of maxillary sinus
Prognostic evaluation of osteoma of maxillary sinus

questions.text: What is the name and its significance of the given line in the image?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Ohngren's line:

  • An imaginary plane is drawn, extending between the medial canthus of the eye and the angle of the mandible.
  • Used for prognostic evaluation of carcinoma of the maxillary sinus.
  • Growths situated above this plane (suprastructural) have a poorer prognosis than those below it (infrastructural).

questions.text: Type of carcinoma of the sinonasal tract in wood-workers is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Woodworkers exposed to hardwood dust have a significantly increased risk of developing sinonasal adenocarcinoma, specifically the intestinal-type adenocarcinoma of the ethmoid sinus and nasal cavity.
  • This subtype is strongly linked to occupations involving wood dust exposure, such as furniture manufacturing and woodworking

Explanation of other options:

Adenoid cystic carcinoma (Option B) is a salivary gland-type tumour found in the sinonasal tract, but is not occupationally associated with wood dust.

Squamous cell carcinoma (Option C) is a common sinonasal malignancy but is linked more to smoking, alcohol, and industrial chemicals, not specifically wood dust.

Olfactory neuroblastoma (Option D), also called esthesioneuroblastoma, is a rare primary tumour of the olfactory epithelium with no known occupational risk factors like wood dust.

choices.text: Stage T4a- Middle cranial fossa involvement
Stage T2-bone of the posterior wall of maxillary sinus

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the T-stage of maxillary sinus carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Stage T3 - Tumour invades any of the following: bone of the posterior wall of maxillary sinus, subcutaneous tissues, floor or medial wall of orbit, pterygoid fossa and ethmoid sinuses.

questions.text: An image shows an incision for maxillary sinus tumour surgery. What is it called?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • The given image shows a Weber-Fergusson incision; it is a standard surgical approach used primarily for access to maxillary sinus tumours and paranasal sinus neoplasms, especially malignancies of the maxilla.
  • Indications:
  • Malignancies of the maxillary sinus
  • Access for total maxillectomy or partial maxillectomy
  • Tumours involving the infraorbital, nasal, and ethmoid regions
  • Tumour extending into the orbit or anterior skull base

Explanation of other options:

Ohngren's line (Option A): It extends from the medial canthus of the eye to the angle of the mandible. This line divides the maxilla into superstructure and infrastructure. The malignancy of the superstructure has a poor prognosis due to its proximity to the orbit.

Gluck Sorenson incision (Option B) is used for total laryngectomy.

Moure's incision (Option D) is used for lateral rhinotomy for medial maxillectomy, which is done in inverted papilloma.

choices.text: Arises from upper part of nasal septum

questions.text: Which statement is false about Ringertz's tumour?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

The Ringertz tumour arises from the lateral wall of the nose.

Inverted Papilloma (Transitional Cell Papilloma or Ringertz Tumour or Schneiderian Papilloma): (Option D)

  • It is a tumour of the non-olfactory mucosaof the nose (Schneiderian membrane) and paranasal sinuses.

Inverted Papilloma or Ringertz tumor

  • The most common site of origin is the lateral wall of the nosein the middle meatus
  • It is a benign but locally invasive tumour and can show malignant conversion. (Option B)
  • Human papillomavirusis thought to be responsible for its aetiology.
  • Clinically, men are affected morethan women in the age group of 40-70. (Option C)
  • Treatment:Medial maxillectomy is the treatment of choice. These days, an endoscopic approach is preferred.
  • Radiotherapy is not advised as it may induce malignancy.

questions.text: Based on the clinical image shown, which of the following best describes the underlying pathology?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Rhinophyma (Potato tumour):

  • Slow-growing and benign
  • Due to hypertrophy of the sebaceous glandsof the tip of the nose
  • Often seen in cases of long-standingacne rosacea.
  • It presents as a pink, lobulated mass over the nose with superficial vascular dilation; it mostly affects men past middle age
  • Treatment: Paring down the bulk of the tumour with a sharp knife or CO2 laser, and the area allowed to re-epithelialize.

questions.text: A patient had a painless, non-healing ulcerative lesion as shown in the picture below for a long time. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

The features suggest basal cell carcinoma (rodent ulcer), the most common nasal skin malignancy, typically affecting the tip or ala.

Rodent ulcer (Basal cell carcinoma):

  • Most common malignant tumour of the skin of the nose (87%) - tip and alacommonly involved.
  • Presents as a cyst or papule-pearly nodule or an ulcer with rolled edgesand contains telangiectatic vessels.
  • Very slow growing but locally destructive.
  • Nodal metastasis - rare
  • High-risk areas for tumour recurrence after initial treatment include:
    • Central face, eg, periorbital region, eyelids, nasolabial fold, nasocheek angle
    • Post auricular region, pinna, ear canal
    • Forehead, scalp

Explanation of other options:

Marjolin's ulcer (Option A): It arises from chronic wounds or scars and has the potential to convert to SCC.

Squamous cell carcinoma (Option D): It is the 2nd most common malignant tumour of the skin of the nose and affects the side of the nose or columella. Presents as an infiltrating nodule or an ulcer with rolled-out edges, with nodal metastases seen in 20% of cases.

Tuberculosis of the nose (Option C): It is a rare disease and affects the Anterior part of the nasal septum and the anterior end of the inferior turbinate.

choices.text: Epithelium undergoes metaplasia from squamous to ciliated columnar

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding rhinitis sicca?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

In rhinitis sicca, the ciliated columnar epithelium undergoes squamous metaplasia with atrophy of seromucinous glands.

Rhinitis sicca:

  • A crust-forming disease seen in those who work in hot, dry and dustysurroundings, like bakers, iron and goldsmiths. (Option B)
  • The anterior 1/3rdof the nose is affected since it is most exposed to the dry air. (Option A)
  • The ciliated columnar epithelium undergoes squamous metaplasiawith atrophy of seromucinous glands.
  • Crust removal → ulceration and epistaxis, and may lead to septal perforation. (Option D)
  • Treatment: Antibiotic and steroid ointment to the affected part.

choices.text: Discontinue oxymetazoline and start steroid nasal spray

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents with complaints of chronic nasal congestion. About 2 months earlier, he had an upper respiratory tract infection with rhinorrhea and nasal congestion. Since then, he continues to have severe nasal congestion for which he uses oxymetazoline nasal spray twice daily. Physical examination showed swollen turbinates and no purulent discharge. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is a case of Rhinitis medicamentosa.

  • Caused due to prolonged useof topical nasal decongestants (α2-adrenergic agonists- xylometazoline, oxymetazoline).
  • These drugs typically cause vasoconstriction. But in case of prolonged usage, they cause rebound congestionand rhinitis due to reflex vasodilation.
  • Oedema and redness of the mucosa, along with hypertrophy of the turbinate, may occur.
  • Treatment:
    • Stop using these nasal decongestant drops
    • Short course of steroidnasal spray
    • Turbinectomy is required in some cases if the turbinates are hypertrophied.

questions.text: A young female presented to the OPD because her friends always complained of a foul smell emanating from her. On examination, a wide, roomy nasal cavity with thick crust formation is seen. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

This is most likely a case of Atrophic rhinitis (Ozaena).

  • It is a progressive atrophy of the nasal mucosa and turbinates.
  • Leads to a wide, roomy nasal cavity.
  • Commonly seen in female sand starts around puberty.
  • There is merciful anosmia (patient is unaware of the foul smell) due to sensory nerve fibre degeneration.
  • Nasal cavity to be full ofgreenish or greyish black dry crusts →Attempts to remove them may cause epistaxis.
  • Klebsiella ozaenaeis a possible aetiology

Explanation of other options:

Rhinosporidiosis (Option B): It presents as a polypoid nasal mass

Rhinoscleroma (Option C): It has atrophic, granulomatous and cicatricial stages.

Rhinitis sicca (Option D): It is a form of chronic rhinitis presenting with crusts on the anterior nasal septum. Removal of crusts causes ulceration and epistaxis.

questions.text: A young lady presenting to the ENT OPD with nasal obstruction, bad smell and crusting in the nose can be offered all of the following treatments except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is a case of atrophic rhinitis. It can be managed medically and surgically. Topical steroid spray is not used for its management.

Medical management: The Goal is to maintain nasal hygiene

  • Nasal irrigation and removal of crusts via warm saline or alkaline douches. An alkaline solution is made by mixing 1 part ;sodium bicarbonate, 2 parts sodium chloride in 280 mL of water. (Option D)
  • 25% glucose in glycerine inhibits the growth of proteolytic organisms, which are responsible for foul smell.
  • Local antibiotics: Eliminate secondary infection. Kemicetine anti-ozena solution contains chloromycetin, oestradiol and vitamin D2 and may be found useful. (Option C)
  • Mucolytics, like potassium iodide to liquefy nasal secretions.
  • Diet: Vitamin A, vitamin D, folic acid, and iron supplementation

Surgical methods include:

  • Young's operation → Complete closure of both nostrils. They are open after 6 months.
  • Modified Young's operation→ Partial closure of nostrils, leaving behind a 3mm hole.
  • Lautenschlaeger technique→ Narrowing of nasal cavities by medial displacement of the lateral wall of the nose. (Option A)

questions.text: Vidian neurectomy is performed in the management of which of the following conditions
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • Vidian neurectomy involves sectioning the parasympathetic fibres of the vidian nerve (nerve of the pterygoid canal), which supplies secretomotor innervation to the nasal mucosa.
  • It is primarily indicated in vasomotor rhinitis, a condition characterised by autonomic imbalance leading to excessive rhinorrhea, nasal obstruction, and paroxysmal sneezing.
  • The procedure reduces nasal secretions by disrupting parasympathetic input.
  • Not used in allergic, atrophic, or drug-induced rhinitis. (Option A, C & D)

choices.text: Pollen is the most common allergen for perennial rhinitis
Ipratropium helps reduce rhinorrhoea in this condition
Sodium chromoglycate is a mast cell stabiliser and is useful in its management

questions.text: All of the following are true about Allergic rhinitis except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The pollen is the most common allergen to cause seasonal allergic rhinitis, and the most common allergen for perennial allergic rhinitis is house dust mite.

  • Allergic rhinitis is a type Iallergic reaction, which is IgE-mediated. (Option A)
    • Early phase:Due to the release of histamine from mast cells.
    • Delayed phase:Due to leukotrienes and prostaglandins. Sodium Cromoglycate is a mast cell stabiliser and hence helpful in its treatment.
  • Ipratropium bromide is an anticholinergic agent that helps reduce the nasal discharge. (Option C)
  • Sodium Cromoglycate prevents mast cell degranulation and thus inhibits release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators.(Option D ruled out)
  • Intranasal corticosteroids(Eg.Fluticasone, Budesonide), Leukotrine receptor antagonist(Eg.Montelukast), antihistamines (Eg.Cetrizine,fexofenadine) are among the other drugs used in the treatment of allergic rhinitis.

questions.text: A patient presents with a roomy nasal cavity, foul-smelling crusts, and a disfigured, hard external nose. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical features are suggestive of Rhinoscleroma.

Rhinoscleroma:

  • Chronic, progressive granulomatousinfection of the external nose, the nasal cavity and the upper lip area.
  • Caused by Gram Gram-negative bacillus called Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis or Frisch bacillus.
  • Clinical features:
    • Atrophic Stage: Resembles atrophic rhinitis.
    • Granulomatous Stage: Subdermal infiltrationof the lower part of the external nose and the upper lip (woody nose). Painless and non-ulcerative nodules in the nasal mucosa.
    • Cicatricial Stage: Due to fibrosis, the patient develops cosmetic deformity.
  • Investigation: Biopsy showing - Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies
  • Treatment: Streptomycin and tetracycline for 4-6 weeks

Explanation of other options:

Atrophic rhinitis (Option A) does not present with a hard, disfigured external nose.

Rhinosporidiosis (Option B) presents as a polypoid mass in the nasal cavity.

Rhinophyma (Option D) presents as a pink lobulated mass over the nose due to sebaceous gland hypertrophy.

choices.text: Russell bodies and Mikulicz cells are classical histopathological features
Can also have similar lesions in oral and genital mucosa

questions.text: A 49-year-old cattle breeder from coastal South India presents with recurrent epistaxis. Anterior rhinoscopy shows a bright red, polypoidal, friable mass in the left nasal cavity. Which statement is not true about this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • The given clinical scenario and the image showing a bright red, polypoidal, lobulated mass with a granular surface appearing friable and vascular in the left nasal cavity are suggestive of
  • Russell bodies and Mikulicz cells are hallmarks of rhinoscleroma (Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis infection), not rhinosporidiosis.

Rhinosporidiosis:

  • Caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, an aquatic protozoan. (Option A)
  • Most cases are from South India, Sri Lanka, and Pakistan.
  • The disease is transmitted through contaminated water of ponds
  • Clinical features:
    • Mostly affects the nose and nasopharynx
    • Other sites such as the lip, palate, conjunctiva, epiglottis, larynx, trachea, bronchi, skin, vulva and vagina may also be affected. (Option D)
    • A mulberry-like polypoidal mass in the nose
    • The mass is very vascular and bleeds easily on touch. Its surface is studded with white dots representing the sporangia.
  • Treatment:
    • Complete excision of the mass with a cutting diathermy and cauterisation of its base.
    • Medical management:Dapsone is a useful drug to prevent recurrence. (Option B)

questions.text: A patient presents with nasal stuffiness and nasal obstruction. On nasal endoscopic examination, he has been found to have bilateral nasal polyps. He also mentions episodes of wheezing and difficulty in breathing, which are resolved by the use of an inhaler. Which of the following drugs would you avoid in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

This presentation is consistent with Aspirin-Exacerbated Respiratory Disease (AERD), also known as Samter';s triad, characterized by nasal polyps, asthma, and NSAID intolerance, making aspirin contraindicated.

Samter's triad:A chronic condition characterized by the triad of:

  1. Asthma
  2. Chronic rhinosinusitis with recurrent nasal polyps
  3. Aspirin/NSAID sensitivity (COX-1 inhibitors)
  • Affects ~9% of adults with asthma,Seen in up to 30% of patients with both asthma and nasal polyps.Typically onset between 20-50 years of age
  • Clinical symptoms:
    • Asthma (often severe and persistent)
    • Nasal congestion, recurrent nasal polyps
    • Loss of smell (anosmia)
    • Chronic sinus infections
    • Respiratory reactions to NSAIDs, e.g.:
    • Wheezing
    • Nasal blockage
    • Bronchospasm following aspirin/NSAID intake
  • Treatment :
    • Avoid NSAIDs (esp. COX-1); acetaminophen ≤500mg is usually safe.
    • Inhaled corticosteroids for asthma control.
    • Intranasal steroids / rinses and short courses of oral steroids for nasal symptoms.
    • Leukotriene inhibitors: Montelukast, Zafirlukast, Zileuton.
    • Surgery (FESS) often needed for polyps; high recurrence without medical control.
    • Aspirin desensitization → allows daily aspirin use; reduces polyp regrowth and steroid need.
    • Biologics (e.g. Dupilumab, Mepolizumab, Omalizumab) for severe asthma and nasal polyps.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with polyp formation in the nose?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Behcet syndrome (ulcers in the oral cavity, genital ulcers and uveitis) is not associated with polyp formation.

Various diseases associated with ethmoidal nasal polyps include:

  • Chronic rhinosinusitisis due to chronic inflammation. Non-allergic rhinitis with eosinophilia syndrome (NARES) is a form of chronic rhinitis associated with polyps.
  • Asthma
  • Aspirin intolerance
  • Cystic fibrosis- due to abnormal mucus. (Option A)
  • Allergic fungal sinusitis
  • Kartagener syndrome- Bronchiectasis, sinusitis, polyposis, situs inversus and ciliary dyskinesis
  • Young syndrome- Sinopulmonary disease, nasal polypi and azoospermia. (Option B)
  • Churg Strauss syndrome- Asthma, fever, eosinophilia, sinusitis, polyposis, vasculitis and granuloma. (Option D)

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the hospital with complaints of nasal stuffiness, headache, sneezing and watery nasal discharge. On examination, polypoid growths are seen in both the nasal cavities. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • In the given clinical scenario the patient has features of nasal stuffiness, headache, sneezing and watery nasal discharge with bilateral polypoid growth on examination is suggestive of Ethmoidal polyps. They are bilateral and multiple caused by allergic rhinosinusitis and mast cell accumulation in nasal mucosa.
  • Killian's polyp, or antrochoanal polyp, is usually seen in children. It is singular and unilateral. Most commonly arises in response to nasal allergy.

Explanation of other options:

  • Killian's polyp (Antrochoanal polyp)(Option A):Typically unilateral, arising from the maxillary sinus (antrochoanal polyp) and projecting posteriorly toward the choana.Most common in children or young adults, not a 40-year-old with bilateral symptoms.
  • Rhinosinusitis(Option C):While rhinosinusitis can cause nasal symptoms and polyps, the specific finding of bilateral polypoid masses fits better under the diagnosis of ethmoidal polyps.

choices.text: Endoscopic removal is the first treatment of choice

questions.text: Which statement is true about Ethmoidal polyp?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Recurrences are more common in Ethmoidal polyps after removal, as they are allergic in origin.
  • Ethmoidal nasal polyps, also called nasal polyps, are often allergic polyps.They form due to chronic allergic rhinitis and the resulting chronic inflammation and edema.
  • Symptoms
    • Bilateral nasal obstruction
    • Sneezing, watery discharge (allergic rhinitis)
    • Hyposmia/anosmia
    • Dull, "closed-nose" voice (rhinolalia clausa)
  • Diagnosis
    • Endoscopy: visualizes bilateral polyps
    • CT scan: shows homogeneous opacities
  • Treatment
    • Topical nasal steroids (first-line)
    • Oral steroids if no response and no contraindications
    • The surgical management is final, FESS is the treatment of choice.

Explanation of other options:

  • Better seen on posterior rhinoscopy(Option A): Ethmoidal polyps are better visualized with anterior rhinoscopy or nasal endoscopy because they arise from the ethmoid sinus and often involve the middle meatus.
  • Endoscopic removal is the first treatment of choice(Option B): Although endoscopic removal is often used for treatment, the first-line treatment for ethmoidal polyps is typically medical management (nasal corticosteroids) to shrink the polyps before considering surgery.
  • More common in children(Option C): Ethmoidal polyps are more common in adults, especially those with chronic rhinosinusitis and allergic rhinitis. Children are more likely to present with Killian's polyps (antrochoanal polyps) rather than ethmoidal polyps.

questions.text: The treatment of choice for the polyp shown in the CT scan is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The CT scan shows a homogenous mass in one maxillary sinus and ipsilateral nasal cavity. So, antrochoanal polyp (Killian's polyp) is the most likely diagnosis.
  • The treatment of choice for antrochoanal polyp is FESS (Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery). If unavailable, endoscopic polypectomy can be done.

Explanation of other options:

  • Intranasal polypectomy(Option A)and Caldwell-Luc operations(Option B) were done previously for antrochoanal polyp.
  • Intranasal ethmoidectomy(Option D): It was done previously for ethmoidal polyp.

questions.text: Which of the following can lead to Rhinolalia clausa?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rhinolalia clausa is hyponasality. This is due to nasal obstruction, nasal polyps, sinusitis, adenoid hypertrophy, and angiofibroma.

Palatal paralysis, cleft palate and velopharyngeal insufficiency cause hypernasality (Rhinolalia aperta).

questions.text: A one-year-old child presents to an ENT specialist with the complaint of a polypoidal mass in the right nasal cavity. What is the best management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This is not a simple polyp because sinuses are still developing in a child, and polyps form as a result of long-standing inflammation.
  • A CT scanis a useful investigation in this case. A polypoidal mass in or around the nose in a one-year-old child can be due tonasal encephalocele, nasal glioma, dermoid, etc.

Dermoid cyst:

  • A dermal implantation cyst occurs in the midline, usually over the dorsum of the nose or scalp.
  • It may present with varied appearances, such as:
    • A simple midline swelling
    • A sinus opening in the center
    • A tuft of hair protruding from the sinus
  • These sinuses may have intracranial communication, especially if located in the naso-frontal or occipital region

Encephalocele or Meningoencephalocele:

  • Herniation of brain tissue along with its meninges through a congenital bony defect.
  • Presents as a subcutaneous pulsatileextranasally at the roof or side of the nose or the anteromedial aspect of the orbit.
  • Swellings show cough impulseand may be reducible.
  • Treatment isneurosurgical.

Glioma:

  • It is a nipped-off portion of encephaloceleduring embryonic development.
  • They can be extranasal (most common), intranasal or both.
  • Extranasal gliomas are encapsulated and can be easily removed by an external nasal approach.

questions.text: A COVID-19 patient presents to the emergency department in a critical state with deranged vitals. The examination shows a blackish necrotic debris in the nasal cavity with necrosed skin of the external nose. What is the best treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is a case of mucormycosis (black fungus).

The ideal treatment includes :

  • Amphotericin B: Liposomal amphotericin B 5mg/kg/day till a response is obtained. Kidney functionshould be monitored.
  • Debridementof all necrotic tissue endoscopically
  • Treatment of underlying diabetes, HIV, COVID, neutropenia or leukopenia
  • Posaconazole is also effective.

choices.text: Black turbinate sign on MRI is characteristic
The HIV status of the patient should be checked

questions.text: Which is a wrong statement about Mucormycosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Mucormycosis is a fungal infection of the nose and sinuses caused by the mucor group of fungi,specifically the Rhizopus group of fungi (molds).
  • This is a life-threatening infection typically seen in immunocompromised patients.
  • Early clinical features:
    • Nasal obstruction
    • Blood-stained nasal discharge
    • Facial symptoms: cheek pain, swelling, heaviness, or numbness (maxillary sinus involvement)
    • Eye symptoms: swelling, blurred vision, diplopia, ocular pain (no black discoloration early)
    • Loose upper teeth (due to fungal invasion of the maxillary
  • Late clinical features:
    • Blackish nasal crusts
    • Black discoloration around the eye
    • Skin necrosis (sign of tissue infarction)
  • Investigation:
    • Tissue biopsy is the gold standard -shows broad, aseptate hyphae with right-angle branching
    • Contrast MRI (if biopsy unavailable): shows black turbinate sign (non-enhancing turbinate on affected side)
  • Treatment:
    • Surgical debridement of necrotic tissue (crucial for drug penetration)
    • Liposomal amphotericin B is the drug of choice (less nephrotoxic)

Explanation of other options:

  • Black turbinate sign on MRI is characteristic (Option A): Black turbinate sign of the inferior turbinate on MRI is characteristic.
  • Angioinvasive fungus (Option C): This is an angioinvasivefungus causing endothelial damage and thrombosis, leading to rapid spread to orbits and brain (fatal) and black ischemic necrosis.
  • The HIV status of the patient should be checked (Option D): Mucormycosis is seen in immunocompromised states like HIV, uncontrolled diabetes, steroid therapy, neutropenia, leukaemia.

questions.text: According to Bent and Kuhn's classification, which of the following is not a major criterion to diagnose allergic fungal rhinosinusitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

Fungal culture is a minor criterion.

Bent and Kuhn Classification of Allergic Fungal Rhinosinusitis:

Major Criteria:

  1. Type I Hypersensitivity (Option A)
  2. Nasal polyposis
  3. Characteristic CT findings (Option D)
  4. Eosinophilic mucin without invasion
  5. Positive fungal stain (Option B)

Minor Criteria:

  • Asthma
  • Unilateral disease
  • Bone erosion
  • Fungal culture (Option C)
  • Serum eosinophilia and Charcot-Leyden crystals

choices.text: Type I and type III allergic reaction
Anti-fungal therapy is the primary treatment modality
Can be seen in immunocompetent patients

questions.text: All are true about the entity shown in the CT scan except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The CT scan shows a heterogeneous appearance characteristic of allergic fungal sinusitis. This is also called double density sign. Antifungal therapy is not the primary treatment.

  • The most common organism is Aspergillus fumigatus.
  • This infection is seen in immunocompetent (Option D)
  • It is a type I and type IIIallergic reaction to fungal antigens. (Option B)
  • Peanut butteris like nasal mucin. (Option A)
  • It has allergic mucinin the nose with nasal polyp formation.
  • These polyps appear heterogeneous on CT scan because of fungal colonies in them (double density sign).
  • The allergic nasal mucin has eosinophils, Charcot-Leyden crystalsand invasive fungal hyphae.
  • MRI is done to rule out invasion of surrounding tissues.
  • The treatment of choice is FESS followed by steroids. The antifungals are only indicated in the invasive variety of fungi.
  • AFRS treatment involves FESS to remove allergic mucin and polyps, followed by long-term topical/systemic steroids, with antifungals reserved for invasive cases

questions.text: A patient presents with chronic nasal obstruction. On anterior rhinoscopy, the inferior turbinate appears pale, boggy, and lobulated, giving a mulberry-like appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A mulberry-like appearance of the nasal mucosa is seen in Inferior turbinate hypertrophy.
  • In allergic rhinitis or chronic rhinitis, the inferior turbinate becomes pale, boggy, and lobulated. It is due to venous engorgement and lobulation of the inferior turbinate that it appears mulberry-like.

Explanation of other options:

Rhinosporidiosis (Option A): This condition produces polypoid masses with bleeding points on the surface.

Rhinoscleroma (Option B): Indurated plaques, not polypoid or mulberry-like

Atrophic rhinitis (Option D): Crusted, dry mucosa; no lobulations or polypoid growths
